name: Kakuna

attacks.name: Stiffen
attacks.text: Flip a coin. If heads, prevent all damage done to Kakuna during your opponent's next turn. (Any other effects of attacks still happen.)

attacks.name: Poisonpowder
attacks.text: Flip a coin. If heads, the Defending Pokémon is now Poisoned.

flavorText: Almost incapable of moving, this Pokémon can only harden its shell to protect itself from predators.

strengths: 80 HP is exceptional for a Stage 1 Pokémon
Stiffen can completely negate damage on successful flip
Low energy requirements for both attacks
Can stall effectively while searching for Beedrill
Poisonpowder adds chip damage over time if successful
High HP makes it difficult for opponents to knock out quickly
Both attacks cost only 2 energy, enabling quick setup
weaknesses: Fire weakness is severe in Fire-heavy meta
Both attacks rely on coin flips, making them unreliable
20 damage from Poisonpowder is very low
Primarily just a stepping stone to Beedrill
Stiffen does no damage, losing offensive tempo
50% chance of Stiffen failing leaves Kakuna vulnerable
Retreat cost of 2 makes switching moderately expensive
synergies: Pokémon Breeder - Can skip Kakuna to reach Beedrill faster
Defender - Stacks with Stiffen for maximum damage reduction
Switch - Helps bypass the 2 retreat cost
Bill - Draws cards to find Beedrill faster
Potion/Super Potion - Extends Kakuna's already high HP
counters: Charizard - Fire weakness and high damage make this unwinnable
Arcanine - Fire typing exploits weakness for massive damage
Moltres - Can OHKO Kakuna despite 80 HP
Energy Removal - Prevents using Stiffen or Poisonpowder
Gust of Wind - Forces Kakuna active before evolution
Pokémon that don't rely on damage - Stiffen doesn't prevent status or effects

description: Kakuna is a Stage 1 Grass-type Pokémon that represents the cocoon stage between Weedle and Beedrill. With an impressive 80 HP for a middle evolution, Kakuna focuses on survival and stalling rather than offense. Stiffen provides a defensive coin flip mechanic that can prevent damage, while Poisonpowder offers a low-damage attack with potential Poison status. While primarily serving as an evolution bridge to Beedrill, Kakuna's high HP gives it unusual durability for a transitional Pokémon.
competitiveHistory: Kakuna saw minimal competitive play in the Base Set era. While its 80 HP was notable, the coin flip reliance and minimal damage output made it impractical as an attacker. Most Beedrill decks used Pokémon Breeder to skip Kakuna entirely, and even when Kakuna was included, it was never intended to see active play. The card's competitive value was essentially zero - it existed purely as a necessary evil for evolution purposes. Even casual players generally preferred to evolve past it rather than utilize its defensive mechanics.

Yes. Stiffen specifically states that other effects still happen. So status conditions, energy removal, or other effects would still apply even though damage is prevented.
Yes. Poisonpowder does 20 damage regardless of the coin flip. The flip only determines whether Poison status is applied.
Yes, but if Stiffen prevents all damage, Defender would have no effect that turn. However, if Stiffen wears off or wasn't successful, Defender would still reduce damage.
Stiffen only prevents damage during your opponent's next turn. After that turn ends, the effect wears off.
